III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Behavior management.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157
Section (2) At a minimum, the behavior management system shall include
Description all of the following:
(b) Positive intervention strategies to assist residents in
developing improved problem solving, self-management, and
social skills.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A AWOLed from school 5/09/24 and returned to the facility
late at night. Staff did not provide youth a blanket and coat when
they asked. Staff directed youth to the door when they stated they
did not want to be at the facility. Youth A went AWOL and was
brought back by law enforcement. Staff are disrespectful towards
this youth.
Investigation This complaint was received on 05/10/2024 and assigned for joint
investigation with MDHHS Specialist.
Interviews:
I interviewed Youth A at the agency on 05/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth A is 14 years old and
has been at the agency for almost two months. Youth A admitted
she AWOLed twice on 05/09/2024. She first AWOL’d from school,
went to the library, and afterwards went to the police station. The
police dropped her off at the agency. The second time she
AWOL’d, was because she asked Staff 2 to give her a blanket and
coat, but Staff 2 was rude. Youth A told Staff 2,” I don’t want to be
here.” Staff 2 told Youth A, “I can’t stop you, so there’s the door,
toodles.” Youth A got up, grabbed her coat, blanket, and walked
out of the agency. Youth A went to the police station and stayed at
the police station for two hours before the police drove her back to
the agency. Youth A said there was another incident when Staff 2
had searched her backpack and found she had obtained a work
permit, Staff 2 started laughing. Staff 2 told her, “You think you are
going to get a job?” and laughed. Youth A could not provide the
specific date or if there were any witnesses to this incident. Youth
A repeated several times she does not want to be at the agency
because the way the staff talk to the youth.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the agency on 05/10/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 1 is the clinical coordinator and was
2

not present on the day in question. She said Youth A had AWOL’d
twice on 05/09/2024. The first time Youth A AWOL’d from school
and the second time was from the agency. Staff 1 said the agency
is an open treatment program and staff will not prevent a youth
from leaving, but they do encourage the youths not to leave. Staff
1 was informed Youth A told Staff 2 she was leaving, and Staff 2
told her she cannot stop her if she wants to leave. Staff 1 reported
Youth A is very defiant and refuses to follow the rules. Youth A
has refused to go to school, participate in therapy, and take her
medication consistently. Staff 1 provided a copy of the incident
report. Staff 1 did not express any concerns for Staff 2.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker via telephone on 05/13/2024.
Foster Care Worker reported Youth A has a history of AWOLing
and not following the rules. She reported Youth A has been at the
agency for almost two months and she has 13 incident reports.
She said Youth A has expressed to her that she wants to go back
to her previous placement, which was a secure placement, and
that she is not happy at her current placement. FCW did not say
she had any concerns for the staff.
I interviewed Supervisor at the agency on 05/13/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Supervisor has been
working at the agency for 5 years. Supervisor reported on
05/09/2024 law enforcement dropped Youth A off after she
AWOLed from school. Supervisor said Youth A was agitated and
defiant. When the police were leaving, they told Youth A to have a
good night and she replied, “I can’t make any promises.”
Supervisor was in the office and Youth A was sitting in the hallway
outside her office with Staff 2. Youth A asked for her coat and
blanket and Supervisor told her they were getting ready to go
upstairs. Youth A became mad and said, “I don’t know why I came
back”. Supervisor told Youth A she has to follow the rules. Youth
A got up, grabbed her coat and blanket and walked out.
Supervisor denied hearing Staff 2 tell Youth A “there’s the door” or
“toodles.” Supervisor said Youth A’s coat and blanket were in her
cubby. She said Staff 2 did say we can’t stop you if you want to
leave. Supervisor contacted the police and filed a police report.
Youth A was dropped off by the police two hours later. She said
Youth A has been behaving and following the rules since the
incident on 05/09/2024. Supervisor denied having any concerns
for Staff 2 and the way Staff 2 spoke with Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the agency on 05/13/2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS Specialist. Staff 2 is a Youth Specialist and has been
working at the agency for one year. Staff 2 reported Youth A was
3

agitated on 05/9/2024, after law enforcement dropped her off.
Staff 2 said Youth A asked for her coat and blanket and she and
Supervisor told Youth A she would be going upstairs to bed, and
Youth A became irritated. She said Youth A got up, grabbed her
coat from the cubby, and walked out. She denied telling Youth A
“there’s the door” or “toodles.” Staff 2 said she did tell Youth A she
cannot stop her if she AWOL’s. Staff 2 said she has previously
talked to Youth A about how dangerous it is to AWOL and
encourages her to make better decisions. Staff 2 denied being
disrespectful to Youth A or any other youth. Staff 2 said there was
one incident where Youth A had a map in her bag, but there was
no incident where she had a work permit. Staff 2 said she has
never laughed or made a comment about Youth A getting a job.
I interviewed Youth B at the agency on 05/13/2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS Specialist. Youth B has been at the
agency for one year. Youth B reported some of the staff are rude
and disrespectful and don’t try to stop them when youth AWOL.
Youth B admitted to AWOLing, and staff have told her “We can’t
stop you.” Youth B initially would not say who the staff member
was, but then she identified Staff 2 as a staff member who is rude
and uses profanity with the youths. Youth B said she didn’t want to
give specific examples or dates, because staff are probably
watching and listening to the interview. Youth B was interviewed in
the living room and there is a camera, but no audio.
I interviewed Youth C at the agency on 07/16/2024. Youth C has
been at the agency for two years. Youth C denied staff are rude or
disrespectful. Youth C admitted she has AWOLed in the past but
could not recall the date. Youth C has heard staff say, “there’s the
door”, when she and other youths threaten to AWOL. Youth C
reported all her needs are being met and expressed no concerns
regarding the staff or the agency.
Video reviewed:
Video footage of 05/09/2024 in the hallway area outside
Supervisor’s office was reviewed on 05/16/2024. (Note: video has
no audio) Youth A was sitting in a chair in the hallway, Youth A
stood up, grabbed her coat and left. Staff 2 walked over to
Supervisor’s office and points to the outside door.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident report dated 05/09/2024 was consistent with
Supervisor interview.
• Agency AWOL Procedures: Staff must always be aware of
each client’s whereabouts. Client is considered AWOL for
4

situations that include running away, skipping school, and
unapproved outings. They must be reported as missing
immediately when their whereabouts are unknown. Staff
must notify law enforcement, relative caregivers/parents,
providers, and DHHS Staff.
• Staff 2’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record.
• Email from Foster Care Supervisor 05/30/2024, stated a
package was sent to Youth A, and the agency would not
allow Youth A to have the package because she was on
restrictions.
• Facility’s Professional Conduct Policy states the facility is
committed to a work environment in which all individuals
are treated with respect and dignity. The policy further
states employees should be respectful, courteous, and
mindful of others.
• Facility’s Behavior Management Policy states appropriate
methods of behavior management include but are not
limited to time-outs, loss of privileges, chores, redirection
and behavioral contracts. Behavioral management methods
should always be appropriate to the age of the child.
Analysis Based on interviews there is insufficient evidence to support the
allegations that staff directed youth to the door when Youth A
threaten to AWOL and that staff are being disrespectful. Per
agency AWOL policy, when a youth AWOLs staff do not stop
them.
CONSULTATION:
Girlstown staff should refrain from using sarcastic remarks when
youths threaten to AWOL. Instead, Staff should discourage the
youths negative behavior by using positive words to redirect them.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program Statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On 5/4/24, staff took youth to be drug screened without a court
order.
5

Investigation Youth A reported all youth were drug screened last week,
because staff found a vape in one of the lockers. Youth A reported
staff search all youth when they come back from school or being
in the community. She denied using drugs or a vape.
Supervisor reported per agency handbook they can drug screen
the youths if they suspect drug or alcohol use. All the youths are
provided with a handbook at admission, and they sign a receipt
indicating they received the handbook. She reported Youth C, who
is no longer at the agency was found to have a vape pen and
marijuana cartridges. Youth C was also known to put things in
Youth A’s locker, so that is why all the youths were drug screened.
Documents Reviewed:
• Girlstown Handbook receipt signed by Youth A dated
03/15/2024.
• Girlstown Handbook states the if the agency suspects drug
or alcohol use, they will require youth to complete a drug
screen and failure to complete a drug screen will be
considered a positive screening.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance per staff interviews and
documentation provided as their program statement allows for
youth to be drug screened if the agency suspects drug or alcohol
use.
CONSULTATION:
It is recommended the agency create and follow policies that align
with the requirements for MDHHS policy and contracts,
specifically addressing drug screens.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
